instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (missing 20v) water damage
threads.message:
This one has me stumped.
PP3V42 is good and was measured at the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s
The <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s appear operational and light up on thermal normally.
None of the rails appear shorted. (but we are not getting 20v at this point)

There was water damage on this board.  Most all the damage was localized round <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>  I had to replace all the pull up 3.3K resistors that were tied to 3V3 TBT X Flash as well as the cap.   I also pulled and inspected <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> for pad damage and reflowed.  

I am not getting 20v on the charger.   I see some chitchat activity and can watch each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> light up on thermal when I move from jack to jack.  Current draw is almost 0.  I have diode checked all around the TI <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips and compared against my reference board.  Everything passes in diode test.  I do not think there is a issue with either of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s and water was not present in this area.

I have read the data sheet on <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and don't see how a serial data storage device could be the cause of this.
I need to learn more about the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s 

If anyone has any input I would greatly appreciate it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (missing 20v) water damage
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> is like a USB-C BIOS for <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, which also connects with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Once I found damaged pads and even lost one trace inside board to <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>; board was never recovered.

Check with o-scope if you get any activity on its MISO/MOSI pins.

Keep in mind, it is very close to backlight filter caps.
An overvoltage (because of liquid) could damaged <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (missing 20v) water damage
threads.message:
I went ahead and replaced <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and it did not change anything.
Looking around the area closer I discovered what could possibly damaged pads under a chip just to the north and east of <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.  I pulled it and found three damaged pads.  One I am not sure where it goes.  My schematic does not show this chip.  

If you had a board view with this chip it would be helpful. 
board shows up as <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01  but this chip is also present on my -A boards.
I have one pad that is in question.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (missing 20v) water damage
threads.message: I was able to get a micro drop of solder on the nub anc curled a jumper I green'ed in place.   Wish me luck because I have no idea where this pad goes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (missing 20v) water damage
threads.message:
After this repair I gave up.  This board is not getting fixed.  
I will harvest it's processor to save a different board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (missing 20v) water damage
threads.message:
That is USB redriver, already posted Aliexpress link to buy it.
The problem is no schematic shows this chip...
I had a board working without that chip, but no USB device recognized...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (missing 20v) water damage
threads.message: I appreciate that input.   It basically tells me that was a rabbit hole anyway.  I decided enough was enough
